DataElement.preferredName: Surgical Procedure Malignant Neoplasm Histology Confirmed Diagnosis Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the type of surgical procedure used to histologically confirm, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains, the presence of a malignant neoplasm, a tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Surgical Procedure Malignant Neoplasm Histology Confirmed Diagnosis
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the surgical procedure used to histologically confirm, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains, the presence of a malignant neoplasm, a tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Used for operative procedures on organs, regions, or tissues in the treatment of diseases, including tissue section by lasers. It excludes transplantation, for which "transplantation" is used.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

Property.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.:Confirmed; having been established or verified.:The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredName: Surgical Procedure Malignant Neoplasm Diagnosis Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the type of surgical procedure used to diagnosis a malignant neoplasm.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A specialty in which manual or operative procedures are used in the treatment of disease, injuries, or deformities.

Concepts.definition: The branch of medical science that treats disease or injury by operative procedures.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of tissue or fluid with a thin needle for examination under a microscope.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue or fluid with a thin needle for examination under a microscope.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Insertion of a thin needle or tube into the abdomen to remove fluid from the peritoneal cavity.

Concepts.definition: The removal of excess fluid via needle puncture from any body cavity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Determination that a value is not relevant in the current context.

Concepts.definition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ReferenceDocuments.name: If primary surgery was not do
ReferenceDocuments.description: If primary surgery was not done, what was the method used to diagnosis disease?
